I'm going to introduce a PR for double factorials shortly, intended for use in a later PR on an explicit formula for the coefficient of a Hermite polynomial. Any suggestions on API? Here's the working definition:

@[simp] def double_factorial : ℕ → ℕ
| 0       := 1
| 1       := 1
| (k + 2) := (k + 2) * double_factorial k

notation n `‼`:10000 := double_factorial n -- this is \!! not two !'s

So far I only plan to have

lemma double_factorial_def (n : ℕ) : (n + 2) ‼ = (n + 2) * n ‼ := rfl
lemma double_factorial_def' (n : ℕ) : (n + 1) ‼ = (n + 1) * (n - 1) ‼ := by { cases n; refl }

maybe n!!∗(n+1)!!=(n+1)!n!! * (n+1)!! = (n+1)!n!!∗(n+1)!!=(n+1)! is another useful lemma? Where do these show up besides Hermite polynomials? Is the genrealization from parity to congruence modulo mmm for general mmm useful at all?

Hmm, I think of double factorials as showing up in combinatorics. For example there are (2n+1)!!(2n+1)!!(2n+1)!! leaf-labeled trivalent trees on n+3n+3n+3 labels. (Also the moduli space of genus 0 stable curves.)
They also come up in Catalan combinatorics, which means they get involved in various objects that involve associativity.

Hmm, another useful lemma would be (2n)!!=2nn!(2n)!! = 2^n n!(2n)!!=2nn!.

I don't think I've encountered the variant with congruence mod mmm.
I see. Maybe some of our resident combinatorialists (I'm certainly not one of them ;)) have some ideas as well?
We should probably have double_factorial n = prod i in range ((n + 1) / 2), (n - 2*i), or whatever the correct statement is
Ugh, nat.sub
How about a subtraction-free version (dependent on whether n is even or odd)?
I'd be happy with a (2n)!!(2n)!!(2n)!! and a (2n+1)!!(2n+1)!!(2n+1)!! formula (that way it also avoids nat division)

Can we skip double factorials and directly go to m-factorials? 1-factorials are factorials, 2-factorials are double factorials, etc... Most of the lemmas you can write about double factorials directly generalise to those.
That's what I meant about congruence mod m above. Where do these m factorials show up (just curious)?

For general $m$, I think mostly you see mnn!m^nn!mnn! for the "mmm-factorial" of mnmnmn, and they quickly show up when you do things with the generalized binomial theorem. I'm not sure I've really encountered the other m−1m-1m−1 of them.
though a priori they're a way to partition a factorial into mmm products, which seems like it must have been useful to someone at some point

I don't think replacing nat.factorial with nat.factorial' 1 is worth the churn (especially mid-port), but I can see the appeal of skipping 2-factorials and having just the 1- special case and the general n- version.

I asked a combinatorialist colleague and she had never encountered the $m$-variation. One thing that's special about m=2m=2m=2 is that the formula @Adam Topaz gave, combined with the formula I gave, means that both (2n)!!(2n)!!(2n)!! and (2n+1)!!(2n+1)!!(2n+1)!! show up individually in various formulas where you can divide out a power of 2. In contrast for m>2m > 2m>2 I don't know where the other terms would show up individually.
Don't all the formulae up-thread hold with the 2s replaced with mmm?

No, n!m⋅(n+1)!m=(n+1)!n!_m \cdot (n+1)!_m = (n+1)!n!m​⋅(n+1)!m​=(n+1)! doesn't hold (I replaced 2 with mmm), though n!m⋅(n+1)!m⋯(n+m−1)!m=(n+m−1)!n!_m\cdot(n+1)!_m\cdots (n+m-1)!_m=(n+m-1)!n!m​⋅(n+1)!m​⋯(n+m−1)!m​=(n+m−1)! does (I made up the notation here).

When m=2m=2m=2 the reason (n+1)!!(n+1)!!(n+1)!! seems to be interesting is that it's the complement of n!!n!!n!! in (n+1)!(n+1)!(n+1)!, like Jake said.
Besides it seeming like there's no math about it yet, one reason against defining nat.factorial' is the question of what nat.factorial' 0 should be...
n!0n!_0n!0​ is the empty product, right? So it should be 1?
Isn’t there some generalized gamma function behind the scenes? That should give us a hint about what this should be.

Isn't the formula n!m=n(n−m)(n−2m)⋯n!_m = n(n-m)(n-2m)\cdotsn!m​=n(n−m)(n−2m)⋯ where the product continues until you get to something less than mmm? There are roughly n/mn/mn/m terms, so n!0n!_0n!0​ is the infinite product n(n−0)(n−2⋅0)(n−3⋅0)⋯n(n-0)(n-2\cdot 0)(n-3\cdot 0)\cdotsn(n−0)(n−2⋅0)(n−3⋅0)⋯

Maybe it’s just n? I was thinking of the fact that Z/0 is Z, so when you take the product of all ints between 1 and n which are congruent mod 0 to n, you get just n. (The gamma function has a shift in the relationship with the factorial, so maybe it does end up being an empty product from that point of view, I don’t know.)

We could look at (mn)!m=mnn!(mn)!_m = m^nn!(mn)!m​=mnn!, so reparameterizing that's (a)!b=ba/b(a/b)!(a)!_b=b^{a/b}(a/b)!(a)!b​=ba/b(a/b)! and you can use a gamma function there to extend it. I wonder if the b→0b\to 0b→0 limit converges here?

Oh, that can't be the right formula... According to this, (5)!2=15π/2(5)!_2 = 15\sqrt{\pi/2}(5)!2​=15π/2​ rather than 151515 :smile:

Anyway, if it were correct then we'd get (0)!0=1(0)!_0=1(0)!0​=1, (1)!0=0(1)!_0=0(1)!0​=0, (2)!0=0(2)!_0=0(2)!0​=0, and then (a)!0=∞(a)!_0=\infty(a)!0​=∞ for a≥3a\geq 3a≥3.
#18994
This has the lemmas suggested by @Adam Topaz and @Kyle Miller, but not multifactorials.

For what it's worth, many of these other generalizations can be formulated as ∏ i in finset.range n, whatever, if they are ever needed. For now, my intended use case is the odd double factorial (which seems to be the one I've encountered most often).
Yeah from the point of view of the gamma function I think the even and odd double factorials are two different functions which interpolate in two different ways
